Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Story:
Last night, as I was rehearsing the prayers for tomorrow’s family ceremony, my phone buzzed. It was Sam, my closest friend. His voice trembled, barely holding together as he told me his father had just been rushed to the hospital. He needed me—someone to listen, to help him make sense of the chaos. I could hear his pain, and every instinct told me to stay on the line, to be the friend he needed right now.

But in the next room, my parents were discussing the ceremony, reminding me how important it was for me to lead, to honor our family’s traditions. They’d been so proud when I agreed to take on this role, trusting me to carry forward what generations before us had cherished. I could feel the weight of their expectations pressing on me, the hope in their voices when they spoke about tomorrow.

Torn between Sam’s desperate need for comfort and my family’s faith in me, I sat in the dark, phone in hand, heart pounding, not knowing which part of me to answer first.
